text: Patient: No. Doctor: So those are things where it's like, oh, this is bad, but it's a fine line where it could be bad. So we will obsess about how are you doing? You know, is there any change? So, those are one of the things that we would check, but we give the same attention on the trial as well as off the trial. You know, if you're getting this regular chemo anyways, we'd ask you the same obsessive questions- Patient: Mhmm. Doctor: How are your feet or your hands. You know what your quality of life, are you losing too much weight, you know, is it too rapid of a weight loss? Are you- you know most people are not nauseous and they don’t throw up, but there's always one in a group you know- are you having problems with that or are your bowels, so we would go down the line like that like we do for Xtandi. And of course now that Xtandi's not working, stop the Xtandi because it's just losses you know kind of drive at the moment, but it's something to consider for later, so we do sometimes go back. Family Member: You're saying Xtandi- Doctor: Mhmm. Family Member: -so he would continue to take the Xtandi along with the chemo? Doctor: No, we would stop it. Family Member: Okay, then I was gonna say I kind of misinterpreted that. Doctor: Yeah, we just stop the Xtandi. Patient: Continue it until I start the trial? Doctor: Nope, you just stop it. It's not doing its thing. If you want to do the trial, or if you're okay with chemo as the next step. But either way Xtandi’s not doing it. So we need to bail out of that. It's just giving you side effects with no gain. Family Member: So how soon would you try to start the new treatment

text: Patient: Right. Doctor: So you know with you, you know what I worry about is sometimes you know, we write prostate cancer on the order form so the doctor over says, “Oh, yeah, there it is, there it is.” Patient: Okay. Doctor: And they may be right, or they may be calling what we normally if you had a scan and they’d say, “ that’s just arthritis, that’s just arthritis, that’s just arthritis”. Patient: Right. Doctor: Prostate Cancer likes to go to the lymph nodes, and so they're oft- they have to start small. And so we all have lymph nodes, but in this case, they say yeah, there’s lymph nodes- Patient: Right. Doctor: -there's a lot of them, so that could be cancer. Patient: Right. DOC. They didn't say it was cancer. It could be cancer. Doctor: The stuff in your back Two different modes of how we look at your back are telling us different things about different places. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: So the tiebreaker really would be to get another test.

text: Patient: Okay. Doctor: So, a good question. It’s something that I have to always make sure people understand. At this stage in the game you should never be on a placebo only trial. Like it can never be either drug X or you’re crap out of luck. No, that’s never gonna happen. Okay? Patient: Okay. Okay. Doctor: And if anybody ever offers you that, that’s bad news. That’s just ethically wrong. So, we have a lot of watchdogs, safeguards, everybody’s looking to make sure that we don’t do something like that. Patient: Okay, Alright. Doctor: Yeah, keep going. Patient: I’ll get these tests done and then we’ll come back to see you. Doctor: Oh, yeah. Patient: And then the rest is done here? Doctor: Yeah. Patient: The treatment is here? Doctor: Yeah.

text: Family Member: Okay. Alright. Yeah. Alright. Doctor: So. Uh. So, I just wrote a quick note to you that sort of says your options for your prostate cancer that is getting worse and that’s why PSA and more disease on bone scan. Okay? That’s how I made that decision. You can go with cabazitaxel chemotherapy, supportive care only. That will just keep you comfortable. Or, a clinical trial, ‘cuz again with cabazitaxel, you’re gonna get supportive care. With clinical trial, you’re gonna get supportive care. You know, we’re always here to make sure you – we keep you comfortable. Uh. The clinical trial, you would need to start the enzalutamide, then have a rising PSA Patient: Yep. Doctor: It could be as short as three weeks from now that everything works. Patient: Uh, huh. Doctor: Okay? But again, the logistics of getting the drug, the logistics of you taking it, logistics of getting a PSA, then you coming back down here and get an ARV seven and then having a week for it to come back, it’s . Okay? Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Um. I’m gonna put the prescription for the enzalutamide in our pharmacy, and they’re gonna do all the work behind the scenes to find out how much it’s gonna cost ya. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Put in the grants and all that other stuff for ya, so that we can get it. Once we know it’s a go, that’s when R_ and I will be back in touch about that. Okay? But you can always back out and say, “This doesn’t make sense. I’m not ready. He’s crazy. We’re not going back to Baltimore.” All of that. Okay? Something bad could happen. You could get in a lot of pain, and they got to treat you right then and there, and this will, will slip past you. Okay? Patient: Yeah. Doctor: But I hope that doesn’t happen. Patient: And even, even this treatment – is successful or just extend me for –

text: Patient: Right. Right. Doctor: So that drug, uh, would be another possible option, because it’s a, it’s an approved drug. I tend to use it in men who have more pain. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Have, you know, multiple bone spots. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: But, right now, we’re doing a trial where we’re giving that drug in combination with a vaccine. The vaccine is called, sipuleucel-T. And that’s the only vaccine we have for any cancer. Both drugs together have shown that they can improve, uh, how long men live with, from prostate cancer. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Uh, and the idea is if we combine them together, would they work together? And there’s some evidence that radiation makes the immune system work better. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: So the complicating part about that study is that the vaccine, you know, is a little involved. You have to go to the Red Cross. They’ve got to call some, they have to kind of hook you up to a machine that kind of pass your blood through and pull out the, the cells that they’re going to make the vaccine out of. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: And so it’s, it’s, you know, you’ve got to do a little bit of work to get the vaccine. Patient: Um hum.

Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.displayed_text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
